NOTES: On 28 March 2019, a bomb was set off in the Shenyang Public Security Bureau Traffic Police Detachment Heping No.1 Brigade in Heping District (Shenyang, Liaoning). 2 police officers and 1 civilian were injured, while the suspect died at the scene. It is suspected that the suspect set off the bomb in retaliation to oppression by the authorities.

On 27 January 2020, a crude homemade bomb exploded in a toilet for persons with disabilities in King George V Memorial Park (Yau Tsim Mong District, Hong Kong). This was the first of three incidents of crude homemade bombs planted in different locations in Hong Kong between 27 and 28 January 2020, reportedly in response to the Hong Kong government's decision to not close the border with Mainland China amid the outbreak of the coronavirus pneumonia.

On 27 January 2020, a crude homemade bomb exploded in a men's toilet of a hospital in Cheung Sha Wan (Sham Shui Po District, Hong Kong). No injuries reported. Two hours later, a post was made by an unknown person on Telegram (a social communications software) claiming responsibility, which stated that this was carried out in response to the Hong Kong government's decision not to close the border with Mainland China amid the outbreak of the coronavirus pneumonia. The post also threatened medical personnel to go on strike. It was further stated that this was conducted as a first warning, and a real bomb targeting the customs will be planned if the demands for border closure and medical staff strike were not met.

On 28 January 2020, a remote-controlled bomb exploded in a garbage can on the Hong Kong area of Shenzhen Bay Port (Nanshan, Guangdong Province). This was the first of three incidents of crude homemade bombs planted in different locations in Hong Kong between 27 and 28 January 2020. The police believed that these bombs were planted in response to the Hong Kong government's decision to not close the border with Mainland China amid the outbreak of the coronavirus pneumonia. No injuries reported.

SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Twitter; Liveuamap
NOTES: On 4 February 2020, a blast went off in a toilet for persons with disabilities near the public library in Lai Chi Kok (Sham Shui Po District, Hong Kong). No injuries were reported, and no arrests were made. This was the second incident of bombs going off in Hong Kong in the same week, and one of a series of bomb blasts in Hong Kong since 27 January 2020.

SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Ming Pao
NOTES: On 4 February 2020, an explosion went off in a public toilet in a park and a large amount of debris was set on fire near the Lai Chi Kok park (Sham Shui Po District, Hong Kong). Initial inspection found that unidentified persons had left large amount of charcoal in the public toilet. The police called the incident part of an ongoing bombing campaign to pressure the government to close its borders with the mainland amid the coronavirus outbreak.

On 29 November 2020, a resident ignited a liquefied petroleum gas canister in 3 Dongjiadu, Huangpu district (Shanghai) (coded as Shanghai-Huangpu), killing himself and causing severe burns to several demolition workers. It was an act of defiance against a forced land seizure and eviction operation implemented by authorities two decades ago, that escalated when the resident's son was kidnapped on the same morning.

On 22 March 2021, a suicide bomber set off a homemade explosive device at a village government committee office in Mingjing village of Panyu district (Guangdong, Guangzhou), resulting in four injured and five dead. The bomber targeted the committee office, which decided on matters linked to land use, after alleged dissatisfaction about monetary compensation regarding a major property redevelopment that involved relocating locals. He was reported to have participated in a range of petitioning and rights defending activities in the past.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (North Korea); Government of South Korea (2017-); Government of North Korea (2011-)
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Pyongyang Times; AP; Arirang Meari; Straits Times (Singapore); VOA; NK Pro; EDaily; Pressian; Seoul Peace Institute; JoongAng Ilbo; Channel News Asia; Dong-a Ilbo; KCNA; Daily NK; NK Economy; SPN; Hankook Ilbo; AFP; Asia News International; Uriminzokkiri; BBC News; South China Morning Post; Rodong Sinmun; Tongil News; Xinhua; YNA; Segye Ilbo; No Cut News; Korea Economic Daily; NEWSIS
NOTES: On 16 June 2020, North Korea bombed the inter-Korean liaison office in Kaesong, which had been established in 2018 as a symbol of the inter-Korean peace process. The act was reportedly in response to anti-regime leaflet campaigns by North Korean defectors in the South. The office was empty, having closed in January 2020 due to COVID-19.
